sect1.title: Dos and Don’ts
sect1.para: Dos and don’ts of diagnostic interviewing in OCD

entry.para: Dos
Don’ts
• Do: Provide psychoeducation on OCD and related disorder symptoms and presentation
– Ensure individuals understand the meaning of obsessions and compulsions
• Do: Create an environment that feels safe for the patient to disclose

– Build trust by setting a tone that this is a judgment-free space to show empathy and encourage patient to be open and transparent about their intrusive thoughts. For children, this could be starting the interaction with asking about their preferred activities and friendships if they are hesitant at the beginning of the interview
• Do: Ask for collateral sources of information
– Such as parents, romantic partners, teachers, and family members to gather a sense of what compulsions may be occurring
– Can be helpful to get information from religious leaders/pastors when necessary or feeling out of one’s scope
• Do: Use evidence-based treatment tools (e. g., CY-BOCS, Y-BOCS)
• Do: Assess for cultural considerations to ensure one is understanding cultural practices or beliefs in context of the individual’s OCD symptoms
• Don’t: Forget to ask about all different subtypes of OCD during clinical interviews
– Assists with obtaining accurate information on full spectrum of OCD symptoms patient is presenting with
– If this is not done, interviewers may miss several OCD symptoms, as there are high degrees of stigma and shame with certain subtypes of OCD that patients may not disclose if not explicitly asked
• Don’t: Further contribute to stigma by showcasing panic, disgust, or alarm when patients speak about their intrusive thoughts/images and compulsions
– Ensure familiarity with all different types of OCD content so that you can speak openly with patients without appearing embarrassed
– This will show them that they can also share details about their OCD
• Don’t: Forget to utilize developmentally appropriate language
– Consider cognitive functioning and age
• Don’t: Rely solely on clinical judgment and expertise to form an OCD diagnosis or evaluation of the severity of symptoms
– Use evidence-based measures
– Ensure you are not misdiagnosing (e. g., psychosis/delusional thinking vs. extreme lack of insight with OCD)
• Don’t: Forget to discuss confidentiality with both children and parents
– Ensure parents understand that content can be sensitive for a child to disclose and may take time for the child to feel comfortable sharing with parent
